The efficient metal- and halogen-free polymer catalyst for the intensification on CO2 cycloaddition Yuanye Zhuang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Shiyang Bai Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization a ⁎ Meng Ge Investigation a Jingjing Sun Formal analysis a Yingying Cheng Data curation a Jihong Sun Resources Project administration Funding acquisition a Yanmin Yu Validation Resources b a Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation, College of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation, College of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing University of Technology Beijing 100124 China Beijing Key Laboratory for Green Catalysis and Separation, College of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China b College of Chemistry and Life Science, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China College of Chemistry and Life Science, Beijing University of Technology Beijing 100124 China College of Chemistry and Life Science, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China ⁎ Corresponding author. An environmentally friendly polymer catalyst (PAS) was synthesized via inverse emulsion polymerization using acrylic acid (AA) and 1-vinyl imidazole (VI) as monomers. The excellent catalytic activity of PAS was attributed to the synergistic effects of the carboxyl groups (-COOH) as hydrogen bond donors and N-heterocyclic carbene (NHCs) as electron donor, as well as the swelling properties of the polymer, which can enrich the substrate into the polymer network, increasing the contact between the substrate and active sites. Characterization results from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) showed that the excessive imidazole addition disrupted the polymer's chain-like structure, significantly reducing its swelling properties. And, the catalytic performance is influenced by both the amount of imidazole in PAS and the swelling properties of the polymer. Finally, the reaction mechanism of the CO2 cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by PAS was proposed and validated through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Graphical Abstract A green catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 was synthesized using a one-step method without metals or halogens. Keywords Inverse emulsion polymerization Eco-friendly polymer catalyst Synergistic effect DFT calculation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, the emission of CO2 has had a severe impact on the ecological environment of the Earth, making it imperative to reduce CO2 emissions [1]. The capture and utilization of CO2 (CCU) technology can capture and enrich CO2, which can then be transformed into more valuable chemical products [2,3]. CO2 is a low-cost, non-toxic, non-flammable, and abundant C1 material that can be converted into high-value chemical products such as urea, synthesis gas, and cyclic carbonates [4]. Among the various valuable chemical products, the reaction of CO2 with epoxides to generate cyclic carbonates is a 100 % atom-economic reaction process [5]. Cyclic carbonates are widely used in battery electrolytes, green solvents, fuel additives, fine chemical raw materials, pharmaceuticals, and other important industrial processes [6–8]. However, Due to the extreme stability of CO2, various catalysts are developed to accelerate the cycloaddition reactions [9]. Currently, the trend in the development of such catalysts is to require high activity and selectivity under mild conditions, as well as good stability and recyclability. Additionally, no co-catalysts nor organic solvents is also required, and the catalyst itself is inexpensive and easy to obtain [10–12]. Over the past decade, a considerable number of catalysts have been reported for the addition reaction of CO2 into epoxides, including ionic liquids, metal halides, metal-organic frameworks, porous organic polymers, metal-organic complexes, ammonium halides, phosphonium halides, imidazolium halides, N-heterocyclic carbenes, and hybrid catalysts [13–24]. Most of these catalysts typically contain metal cations or halide anions [25]. Although these catalytic systems exhibit excellent catalytic activity, they often suffer from issues such as need for co-catalysts or organic solvents, toxicity of metal active centres or halides, harm to the environment, and complex or expensive catalyst preparation [26–30]. Therefore, with respect to green processes, metal waste and harmful halides should be avoided by using metal- and halogen-free catalysts. Recently, it has been found that hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups (such as -NH2, -OH, -COOH) can coordinate with the epoxide oxygen to form hydrogen bonds, polarizing the C-O bond of the epoxide and promoting its ring-opening [31–34]. Therefore, catalysts containing HBD groups can effectively replace those containing metal ions [35]. When the catalytic performances of hydroxyl-, carboxyl-, and amino-functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquids (FPBILs) were compared in the addition reaction of CO2 to epoxides, it was found that catalysts with carboxyl group exhibited the highest catalytic activity [6]. However, simple HBD groups cannot serve as catalysts for the reaction between CO2 and epoxides because they lack the required nucleophilic attack activity for the ring-opening of epoxides [10]. So, in HBD containing catalytic system, additional halide ions, which act as the nucleophilic groups, are necessary. Fortunately, N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have strong electron-donating ability, exhibiting strong nucleophilicity and Lewis basicity, and can be used as nucleophilic reagents to promote the ring-opening of epoxides and the activation of CO2 [36]. Some catalysts rich in both -COOH and N-heterocyclic carbene often exhibited excellent catalytic performance without any co-catalyst [37]. The design strategy for such catalysts typically involves constructing a porous structure to enhance CO2 adsorption. However, the relatively high CO2 pressure was still required in the reactions [38–42]. Herein, based on the above concepts about the catalyst used in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides, a novel metal-free and halogen-free polymer catalyst (PAS), which contained both -COOH as HBD and imidazole as nucleophile was designed. The PAS was synthesized via reverse emulsion polymerization using acrylic acid (AA) and 1-vinyl imidazole (VI) as monomers. A cross-linked network was found to be formed in PAS, which could provide excellent stability and swelling properties in organic solvents, therefore acting as a micro-reactor to enhance the contact between the reactants and the catalyst. In the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides, PAS exhibited excellent catalytic activity under solvent-free and co-catalyst-free conditions. The effects of polymer structure, reaction parameters, the reactivity of different epoxides, and the reusability of the catalyst were investigated in detail. Moreover, the catalytic active site was determined by experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, through which a one-step process mechanism, including simultaneous epoxide ring-opening and CO2 insertion, was proposed for the first time. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials 1-Ethylimidazole (VI, ≥98.0 %), Span 80 (LR), and Tween 80 (LR) were purchased from Shanghai Dibo Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Liquid paraffin (AR) and epichlorohydrin (ECH, AR) were bought from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Ethyl acetate (AR), azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, AR), and n-hexane (AR) were purchased from Fuchen (Tianjin) Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Acrylic acid (AR) was purchased from Beijing Tongguang Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Deuterated chloroform (D, 99.8 %, TMS 0.03 %) was purchased from Beijing Bailingwei Technology Co., Ltd. Carbon dioxide (99.9 %) was purchased from Beijing Shuangquan Tianyuan Industrial Gas Co., Ltd. Except for AIBN, all reagents were of analytical grade and could be used without further purification. The AIBN used in the experiment was purified using the following method: 5 g of AIBN was added to a 50 mL methanol solution and stirred until dissolved. The solution was then heated at 50 °C in an oil bath for 10 minutes and filtered. The filtrate was cooled in an ice-water bath for 30 minutes to precipitate needle-like crystals, which were then filtered. The filtered crystals were dried to obtain purified AIBN. 2.2 Synthesis of samples PAS was prepared by copolymerization of AA and VI via reverse emulsion polymerization. The oil phase, comprising 68 wt% liquid paraffin and 2 % emulsifier. The emulsifier was composed of a mixture of Span 80 and Tween 80 at a ratio of 75:25. The aqueous phase contained 10 % AA, x% VI (where x=0, 10, 20, 50, representing different amounts of VI), and 20 % water. Under magnetic stirring at 300 rpm, the aqueous phase was gradually added dropwise into the oil phase, which dissolved the emulsifier. The emulsion was heated to 65 °C and purged with nitrogen for 30 minutes to remove residual oxygen. Then, 0.125 wt% AIBN was added, and the reaction was maintained at 65 °C for 4 hours. After cooling to room temperature, particles were isolated through centrifugation, washed alternatively with n-hexane and water several times and then freeze-dried to remove residual solvent and water. PAS with different amounts of VI was obtained and designated as PAS-x (x=0, 10, 20, 50). 2.3 Investigation of swelling behavior To investigate the swelling behavior of samples with different amounts of imidazole additives, an appropriate amount of sample was first compressed under the condition of 10 bar for 1 minute. The water absorption of the polymer was determined using the gravimetric analysis method. The compressed samples were placed in small bottles, and 10 mL of deionized water was added, followed by soaking for 4 hours. The water in the bottles was then absorbed using filter paper and weighed. The swelling ratio (SR) is calculated using the Eq. (1) as shown below: (1) SR % = W t − W d W d * 100 % Where W d is the mass of the freeze-dried sample, and W t is the mass of the sample after 4 hours of swelling. 2.4 The cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide At room temperature, a specific amount of epoxide and catalyst were added to a 25 mL stainless steel high-pressure reactor. CO2 was then introduced, and the reactor was purged three times to remove residual air, adjusting the pressure to 5 bar. Using a thermal bath and magnetic stirrer, a heating program was set to raise the temperature from room temperature to the target temperature at a rate of 5 °C/min, maintaining the temperature for a specified period. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was immediately removed, cooled in an ice bath, and the CO2 was slowly released. 1H NMR analyzed the product. After the reaction, the catalyst was thoroughly cleaned with ethyl acetate and dichloromethane and dried at 60 °C for 6 hours. The dried catalyst could be used for catalytic cycle experiments. 2.5 Computational details Geometry optimization and frequency calculations were performed using the DFT method implemented in Gaussian 16. Due to the good performance of B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6–311+G** in similar systems, it was chosen for all geometry calculations [43]. Firstly, the reactants and catalysts involved in the reaction were subjected to geometry optimization and frequency calculations, and the interactions between them were evaluated. The frequency calculations showed no imaginary frequencies and bond lengths and bond angles were expressed in angstroms (Å) and degrees (°), respectively. Subsequently, the actual accurate transition state was determined using transition state search functions, and a transition state value with an imaginary frequency was obtained. The given transition state was verified using the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) theory, ensuring good connectivity to neighboring minima. Based on the geometry optimization, single-point energy calculations were performed using the more advanced M06–2X-D3/ma-def-TZVP basis set. System energy corrections, considering the zero-point energy (ZPE), temperature (120 °C), and pressure (5 bar) effects, were calculated using the Shermo program [44]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation of polymer catalyst PAS Scheme 1 depicted the procedure for synthesizing PAS. The polymer catalyst was made via the inverse emulsion polymerization technique, employing acrylic acid and 1-vinyl imidazole. The oil phase consisted of liquid paraffin and emulsifiers. The liquid phase contained polymer monomers and water. Acrylic acid, which has a large number of carboxyl groups, functions as a hydrogen bond donor to activate epoxides, hence promoting the opening of the epoxide ring. Simultaneously, the nitrogen atoms in imidazole facilitated the activation of CO2, leading to its incorporation into epoxides and resulting in the formation of half-ester intermediates. The combined effect of these components significantly improved the cycloaddition process between CO2 and epoxides. 3.2 Characterization of catalytic materials The chemical composition and structural changes of the prepared catalyst were characterized using FT-IR spectroscopy ( Fig. 1A). In the prepared catalyst, the absorption peaks observed at 2926, 1725, and 1264 cm−1 were attributed to the C-H stretching vibration, CO stretching vibration, and C-O stretching vibration, respectively [45]. Additionally, a new absorption peak corresponding to the CC stretching vibration of the imidazole group appears at 1558 cm−1 in PAS-10, 20, 50, indicating the successful incorporation of imidazole into the polymer [46]. The chemical characteristics of the polymer were investigated using solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 1 B). In the spectrum of PAS-0, two peaks are observed at 42 ppm, which are attributed to the -CH- and -CH2- moieties in the polymer chain [47]. The peak at 180 ppm is assigned to carbonyl carbons. After the addition of imidazole, except for the aforementioned characteristic peaks, a peak belonging to the carbon atom in the imidazole moiety is observed at 120 ppm, suggesting the successful copolymerization of AA and VI [48]. The loading capacity of imidazole in the polymers was deduced from the content of nitrogen obtained by elemental analysis (EA) and is presented in Table 1. As the amount of imidazole increased in the initial preparation oil phase, the content of imidazole in the polymer increased, indicating controllable copolymerization. The surface composition of PAS-20 was analyzed using XPS measurements, and the corresponding spectra are shown in Fig. 2 A-D. The spectra indicate the presence of C, N, and O elements in PAS-20. The C 1 s spectrum of PAS-20 exhibits three distinct peaks at 284.8, 286.2, and 288.9 eV, which can be attributed to the C-C bonds in the polymer chain, the C-O bonds and the CO bonds in the carboxyl groups, respectively [49]. The N 1 s spectrum shows a prominent peak at 401.5 eV, corresponding to the N-C/NC bonds in the imidazole ring [50]. The O 1 s spectrum displays a distinct peak at 532.5 eV, which is attributed to CO groups [51]. The morphology of polymers with different imidazole addition levels was observed by SEM, as shown in Fig. 3 A-E. The polymers are co-polymerized via the inverse emulsion method, and due to severe agglomeration, all exhibit a block-like morphology with surface protrusions. The polymer without imidazole addition, PAS-0, has a relatively smooth surface without any particle protrusions. The copolymerization of imidazole results in the appearance of particle protrusions on the polymer surface, and with increasing imidazole addition, the particle protrusions become more abundant (Fig. 3 B, C), while the particle size also decreases (from approximately 150 nm to 70 nm). However, excessive imidazole addition led to the re-smoothing of the polymer surface (Fig. 2 D), possibly due to the interaction between imidazole and the carboxyl groups of the polymer, causing polymer shrinkage. The polymer's swelling behavior was assessed by immersing it in deionized water at room temperature. Fig. 4A demonstrates that the polymer PAS-0, when not combined with imidazole, exhibited a swelling ratio of 6216 %. Nevertheless, with the increasing presence of imidazole, the swelling ratios of PAS-10, PAS-20, and PAS-50 exhibited a progressive decline, reaching 779 %, 642 %, and 195 %, respectively. The decrease in swelling capacity was attributed to the copolymerization of imidazole, which disrupts the hydrogen link between the carbonyl group and water. Despite significantly reducing in swelling properties compared to PAS-0, PAS-x (x>0) still demonstrated a cross-linked rod-like or elliptical morphology when swollen, as observed in Fig. 3 E. Conducting a swelling experiment using PAS-20 in an ECH solution simultaneously, the swelling rate of PAS-20 reached 311 % (as shown in Figure S1). This suggests that the polymer retains its ability to expand its framework even after introducing of solvent. The good swelling properties were expected to support the enrichment of substrates in the reaction. The TG and curves in Fig. 4 B-C depict the thermal stabilities of the polymers. The weight of all samples decreases within the temperature range of 30–120 °C due to the evaporation of moisture and residual solvents present in the polymer. The loss of weight observed between the temperature range of 140–320 °C is a result of the decarboxylation process of the polymer. On the other hand, the weight loss occurring between 330 and 530 °C is caused by the degradation of the polymer chains [52,53]. According to the literature, in the polymer the decomposition temperature of the side chains is lower than that of the main chain [54]. The copolymerization of imidazole exerts a notable influence on the decarboxylation process of the polymer, suggesting that imidazole interacts with carboxyl groups, resulting in a reduced decomposition temperature of the polymer's carboxyl groups. With the addition of imidazole, the maximum weight loss rate temperature of PAS-10 in the range of 330–530 °C increases, attributed to the enhanced thermal stability of the catalyst's main chain resulting from the successful polymerization of imidazole. The maximum weight loss rate temperature of PAS-20 in the range of 330–530 °C decreases, which is attributed to the increased addition of imidazole groups leading to the influence of side chain degradation. When an excessive amount of imidazole is introduced (as depicted in Fig. 4 C d), it modifies the thermal degradation process of the polymer. The DTG curve of the polymer undergoes a transition from a bimodal peak shape to an unimodal peak shape throughout the temperature range of 140–530 °C. This suggests that the decarboxylation process of the polymer coincides with the decomposition process of the polymer chains. The addition of excessive imidazole is inferred to modify the initial linear structure of the polymer, perhaps resulting in the formation of a crosslink structure between imidazole and carboxyl. This is further supported by the findings of the swelling test. The fractal evolution curve of the given sample was derived using the small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) technique, as depicted in Fig. 4 D. The precise numerical values for the fractal dimension and the range used for linear fitting in the system are presented in Table 1. Fig. 3 illustrates the process of obtaining linear segments inside the low-q range (0.10 < q < 0.14) and high-q range (0.34 < q < 0.47) using linear least squares fitting [55]. The mass (or surface) fractal dimensions (D m or D s ) are calculated based on the power-law decay of the displacement scattering curve (In[I(q)] ∼ In q). This allows for the examination of the fractal properties of the sample. In the low-q area, the sample PAS-0 exhibits fractal properties without imidazole. These fractals are classified as mass fractals, with a fractal dimension (D m ) of 2.86. This suggests that the polymer has a well-connected network structure and is in a somewhat loose condition. When imidazole and acrylic acid are copolymerized (as depicted in Fig. 4D b), the catalyst's fractal properties shift from mass fractals to surface fractals. This change suggests that the polymer transforms from a loose to a dense state. These findings indicate that the presence of imidazole causes a reduction in the size of the polymer structure. The imidazole groups interact with the carboxyl groups of the polymer by hydrogen bonding, leading to the contraction of the polymer into a compact state and a reduction in its swelling ability. Moreover, as the number of imidazole groups increases (as depicted in Fig. 4 D b-d), the surface fractal dimension of the catalyst decreases from 2.32 to 2.14. This suggests that the presence of imidazole groups in the polymer leads to the contraction of the polymer network, causing the polymer surface to transition from a rough texture to a smooth one. The fractionation features of the catalyst in the high-q area closely resemble those in the low-q region. Nevertheless, the surface fractionation of PAS-50 with the greatest imidazole content rises to 2.44. This suggests that the excessive inclusion of imidazole during the polymer synthesis may disturb the polymer's chain-like structure and result in random copolymerization, causing the previously smooth polymer surface to become rough. This aligns with the data acquired from the TG/DTG study. 3.3 Catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides The study assessed the catalytic efficiency of catalysts produced for CO2 cycloaddition processes, ECH as an epoxide. The results are presented in Table 2. The ribbon in PAS has exposed sites of -COOH and imidazole groups, which can potentially act as hydrogen bond donors and Brønsted base groups, respectively. The experiment was conducted at mild conditions of 5 bar pressure and 120 °C temperature, with a notable increase in substrate utilization. The conversion of ECH (Table 2, entry 1) was merely 10 % in the absence of a catalyst. In addition, the ring-opening reaction showed no improvement with the presence of acrylic acid and PAS-0 (Table 2, entries 2 and 3). This suggests that molecules containing solely the HBD group recognized as an epoxide activator, do not exhibit significant catalytic activity. Nevertheless, the 1-vinylimidazole exhibited superior catalytic efficacy in the ring-opening reaction, as indicated by Table 2 entry 3, achieving a conversion rate of 66 % for ECH. The imidazole group possesses a high level of basicity, enabling it to activate CO2. In addition, the combination of acrylic acid and 1-vinylimidazole resulted in enhanced catalytic activity (as shown in Table 2, entry 4) compared to using only 1-vinylimidazole. This led to a successful conversion of 78 % of ECH. This experiment illustrates that acrylic acid, functioning as a hydrogen bond donor (HBD) chemical, can effectively enhance the ring-opening reaction when combined with 1-vinylimidazole. When the catalyst PAS-20 was utilized (as indicated in Table 2, entry 7), it exhibited outstanding catalytic efficacy, resulting in a conversion rate of 87 %. When VI was copolymerized into PAS to create a polymer, it allowed the substrate to be absorbed into the polymer network. This led to improved interaction between the substrates and catalytic active sites, resulting in better catalytic performance compared to the physical mixture. With the increase in imidazole content, the ECH conversion of PAS-0, PAS-10, PAS-20, and PAS-50 (Table 2 entry 5, 7, 8, 9) was 11 %, 79 %, 87 %, and 81 % correspondingly. At low imidazole content, the polymer exhibited favourable swelling characteristics. However, the scarcity of catalytic active sites led to subpar catalytic activity. On the other hand, while the polymer's abundant imidazole groups increased the number of catalytic centers, they also caused a reduction in the polymer's ability to swell. As a result, there was not enough contact between the reactant substrates and the catalytic active sites. In order to assess the performance of PAS catalysts, we compared our findings with those of other heterogeneous catalysts that share a comparable structure, specifically a structure devoid of metals and halides. Table 3 illustrates that PAS-20 exhibits reduced catalyst quantity and increased catalytic activity in the absence of any cocatalyst. In addition, compared to other catalysts often employed for this reaction (as shown in Table S3), PAS-20 demonstrates greater catalytic efficiency even at milder reaction conditions. Under the optimum conditions, a range of epoxides was analyzed to assess the potential of the PAS catalyst ( Table 4). PAS demonstrated exceptional catalytic efficiency, leading to highly successful conversions in the majority of reactions. Out of the four epoxides that were evaluated, PAS-20 shown superior catalytic effectiveness towards ECH (as shown in Table 4, entry 1) when compared to the other substrates. ECH has substituents that remove electrons, reducing the electron density of the epoxide. This makes it easier for nucleophilic reagents to replace the epoxide [58]. Curiously, as the carbon chain lengthens, the catalytic activity of the process remains almost constant. According to Table 3, Entry 2–3, propylene oxide (PO) achieved an 85 % conversion rate, with 96 % selectivity towards the cyclic carbonate (Table 4, Entry 2). By comparison, a conversion rate of 86 % was achieved for butylene oxide, with a selectivity of 98 % towards carbonate (Table 4, entry 3). This could be attributed to the swelling properties of PAS, where the reactants are able to be absorbed into the polymer network, resulting in a substantial decrease in the spatial effects of epoxides. Cyclohexene oxide, one of the commonly found epoxides, typically showed the lowest catalytic efficiency compared to other epoxides. This can be attributed to its higher steric hindrance and the presence of a six-membered ring structure, which hampers its reactivity [59]. Table S4 compares the catalytic performance of several analogous catalysts for cyclohexene oxide, revealing that the present catalyst maintains effective catalytic activity even for substrates with significant steric hindrance. Furthermore, the investigation of catalyst recovery was conducted by employing PAS-20 as a catalyst. During each run, the catalyst was effortlessly gathered using centrifugation, and the molar ratio of epoxide to catalyst remained constant. Fig. 5A demonstrates that the catalyst can be utilized multiple times, with a minimum of five times, while maintaining both high activity and selectivity. The minor reduction in activity was primarily ascribed to the deposition of the reaction products on the polymer, as evidenced by SAXS (Figure S5 and Table S5) and N2 adsorption-desorption studies (Figure S6 and Table S6) (complete data are included in the Supporting Information). The reaction kinetics were examined by employing PAS-20 as a catalyst and ECH as the substrate at various temperatures [60]. The correlation between the natural logarithm of the concentration of ECH and time demonstrates that the reaction adheres to first-order kinetics. The specific calculations are presented in equations S4-S9. The Arrhenius plot (Fig. 5 B) was achieved based on the linear fitting of lnk vs. 1000/T from 60 °C to 80 °C. This analysis yielded an apparent activation energy (Ea) value of 31.72 kJ∙mol−1, which low as compared to many other reported catalysts. (Detailed comparison information is shown in Table S7) 3.4 Cycloaddition reaction mechanism: DFT-supported study A mechanical framework for the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and ECH was provided, based on previous investigations, empirical findings, and computer analysis using Density Functional Theory (DFT) [61]. The DFT method has been used to accurately describe the configurational interactions between the catalyst and the reactants. Given the replicability of structural motifs within PAS-20 and the feasibility of optimization computations, a representative edge group structure encompassing all pertinent functional groups was strategically chosen for optimization. Fig. 6 A-B illustrates the aforementioned structure and the geometrically optimal arrangement between CO2 and ECH. Inside the catalyst, the carboxyl group creates a hydrogen connection with the oxygen in ECH, resulting in significant changes in bond lengths and angles after geometric optimization. The Cα-O and Cβ-O bonds in ECH change from lengths of 1.43125 Å and 1.42750 Å to lengths of 1.44913 Å and 1.44371 Å, respectively. Additionally, the angles ∠OCαCβ and ∠OCβCα increase from 58.93676° and 59.18777° to 59.30978° and 59.67406°, respectively. This transition highlights the ability of the carboxyl group to donate hydrogen bonds and its resulting polarization of the C-O bond in ECH, which helps in breaking and opening the C-O bond. Simultaneously, the nitrogen atom on the imidazole ring plays a crucial role in activating CO2. The optimum bond lengths of CO2 change from 1.16074 Å to 1.16127 Å and 1.16161 Å, while the bond angle adjusts from 180° to 175.64606°. The activating ability of imidazole on CO2 is demonstrated by its promotion of CO2 insertion. Fig. 7 displays the relative free energy barrier of the PAS and non-catalyst for the CO2-ECH cycloaddition reaction. We utilized the edge group structure mentioned above to model the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and ECH, catalyzed by PAS. During the initial reaction process, ECH and CO2 were adsorbed onto the PAS surface using the -COOH and imidazole ring to activate the epoxy ring and CO2 (Int1). The ECH ring-opening and CO2 insertion occurred simultaneously, with a barrier of 18.98 kcal/mol (TS1). This barrier was significantly lower than the 67.58 kcal/mol seen in the uncatalyzed cycloaddition of CO2. The calculated imaginary frequency of 425.65i cm–1 suggests breaking the Cα-O link in ECH and the subsequent creation of a bond between Cα in ECH and O in CO2. In the intermediate state Int2, the alkoxide anion achieved stability by forming a stable intermediate through electrostatic interaction with the hydrogen atom of the carboxyl group in PAS. Subsequently, the cyclic carbonate was synthesized, and the catalyst was regenerated. The barrier for ring-closure, as determined by calculation, was found to be 3.18 kcal/mol (TS2). The calculated imaginary frequency of 429.33i cm–1 represents the breaking of the hydrogen link between the alkoxide anion and carboxyl group and the creation of a bond between the alkoxide anion and the carbon atom in CO2. Overall, DFT calculations determined that the ring-opening of ECH is the step in the reaction that limits its rate. This step has a maximum energy barrier of 18.98 kcal/mol, which can be easily overcome. The results confirmed that PAS is effective in promoting the cycloaddition reaction of CO2, even without needing co-catalysts or organic solvents. Furthermore, the simultaneous occurrence of epoxide ring-opening and CO2 insertion in a one-step mechanism has been established with supporting data. Using the mechanistic investigations and DFT calculations mentioned earlier, a tentative mechanistic hypothesis has been provided for the CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reaction using PAS as the catalyst, as seen in Scheme 2. The nitrogen atoms in the imidazole groups of PAS are the basic adsorption sites, acting as crucial sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2. Within this particular framework, imidazole and CO2 combine to create a conjugated system, which aids in the movement of unshared electron pairs from the imidazole molecule to the empty orbitals of the CO2 molecule. As a result, an imidazole ion with a positive charge is produced, while a CO2 ion with a negative charge is formed. Simultaneously, the carboxyl group (-COOH) in PAS acts as a hydrogen bond donor (HBD) group, forming a hydrogen bond with the oxygen atom in the epoxide. This interaction causes the C-O bond in the epoxide to become polarized, resulting in a decrease in its electron cloud density. As a result, the Cβ + bond in the epoxide, which has a lower density of electrons, can be easily broken by the polarization of a hydrogen bond. This results in the creation of an intermediate compound. Afterward, the negatively charged oxygen atom of the activated carbon dioxide reacts with the positively charged carbon atom of the opening epoxide to create a new C-O bond, resulting in the production of a carbonic semi-ester molecule. The establishment of this hydrogen bond is crucial in facilitating the effective activation and opening of the epoxide ring. Afterwards, the negatively charged oxygen atom in the epoxide group of the carbonic semi-ester complex undergoes a reaction where it attacks the carbon atom in the CO2 group inside the same molecule, resulting in the formation of a ring. Ultimately, the hydrogen connection becomes less strong, causing the cyclic carbonate to detach from the nitrogen adsorption site, starting the next catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions PAS is an organic copolymer that is prepared easily with low cost. As a new type of non-metallic, non-halide heterogeneous catalyst, PAS can efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 under co-catalyst-free conditions. The results indicate that the catalytic activity of PAS is derived from the synergistic effect of the HBD group (-COOH) and the sub-amino group (-N=) on the imidazole ring. The functional groups of -COOH and imidazole can effectively replace the roles of metal ions and halides in catalysis, respectively. Moreover, the polymer has swelling properties, which can enrich substrates and facilitate contact between reactants and active centres. Alongside, the effect of imidazole addition on the polymer's swelling properties was elucidated through characterization via TG and SAXS. Furthermore, through DFT calculations, the significance of hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups and sub-amino (-N=) functionalities within the PAS system was explicitly discussed in the context of the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and epoxides. Additionally, the potential energy surface changes for the reaction catalyzed by the PAS catalyst were computed, verifying the one-step process wherein the epoxide ring-opening and CO2 insertion occur simultaneously for the first time. PAS catalyst has the advantages of simple preparation, excellent catalytic activity, and good cyclic stability, making it of practical value. coredata.dc:description: An environmentally friendly polymer catalyst (PAS) was synthesized via inverse emulsion polymerization using acrylic acid (AA) and 1-vinyl imidazole (VI) as monomers. The excellent catalytic activity of PAS was attributed to the synergistic effects of the carboxyl groups (-COOH) as hydrogen bond donors and N-heterocyclic carbene (NHCs) as electron donor, as well as the swelling properties of the polymer, which can enrich the substrate into the polymer network, increasing the contact between the substrate and active sites. Characterization results from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) showed that the excessive imidazole addition disrupted the polymer's chain-like structure, significantly reducing its swelling properties. And, the catalytic performance is influenced by both the amount of imidazole in PAS and the swelling properties of the polymer. Finally, the reaction mechanism of the CO2 cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by PAS was proposed and validated through density functional theory (DFT) calculations.
